data.text: A digital euro would complement cash, not replace it: together they would offer people a greater choice and easier access to ways of paying. This should help financial inclusion and promote innovation in the field of retail payments https://t.co/RiwOCers68 2/3

(THREAD) As technological changes are transforming how we pay, a digital euro could offer a universally accepted, risk-free and trusted means of payment to complement cash. We’ve analysed its possible benefits and challenges in our report https://t.co/RiwOCers68 1/3 https://t.co/FLv1eRAkBL

Enria: A proactive attitude is needed on all sides. This includes authorities’ initiatives to make reducing bad loans easier, as well as improving banks’ weak profitability by reshaping business models or through consolidation https://t.co/agpQ7jE4hd 4/4

Enria: Banks must brace for the deterioration of asset quality that is likely to materialise as the system-wide payment moratoria are lifted. Adequate management of risks and non-performing loans is key to avoiding costly cliff effects 3/4
Enria: Our immediate relief and capital conservation measures have proven to be effective, with banks planning to expand their loan books. Now our supervisory strategy has moved into a new phase 2/4

(THREAD) After the initial crisis response, banks and supervisors should now look beyond the pandemic, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria at the @EBFeu public dialogue on European banking beyond the pandemic 1/4 https://t.co/LRcl6kTZAa

De Guindos: The PEPP is a temporary emergency programme, tailor-made to deal with the pandemic. More than half of the envelope remains available, so we still have ammunition. We have extended the programme and can adjust and recalibrate if necessary https://t.co/rboqVNaT9r 2/2

(THREAD) Talking about the economic outlook and fiscal policy, ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos says fiscal policy focus has to be on those countries that are hit hardest and where the decline in GDP clearly exceeds the average 8% of the baseline scenario 1/2 https://t.co/m2ruTnSUVG

This year's #ECBForum on Central Banking will take place online on 11 and 12 November. Discussions will focus on central banks in a shifting world. Here is the programme as it stands https://t.co/P93rcohD3D https://t.co/BSNJhFNO62
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (Aug 2020) https://t.co/pVf6EJC6L4

Mersch: By implementing stricter and more intrusive fit and proper assessments we go one step further in closing existing gaps between countries. This raising of the bar will be accompanied by more transparency to better convey our expectations https://t.co/iZoOaBqFuv 3/3

Mersch: The integrity and competence of a bank’s directors is one of the most important lines of defence against mismanagement and fraud. The ECB performs the ultimate suitability quality control – the fit and proper assessment – for the biggest banks in the euro area 2/3

(THREAD) The ECB’s fit and proper assessments of the suitability of banks’ directors will become stricter and more intrusive, Supervisory Board Vice-Chair Yves Mersch writes in an opinion piece. In doing so we are raising the bar for bank governance https://t.co/iZoOaBqFuv 1/3 https://t.co/6brqeKVmIU

As of today the ECB supervises significant Bulgarian and Croatian banks and the countries’ supervisors join our Supervisory Board with full voting rights. For the first time European banking supervision expands beyond the euro area. https://t.co/VAgE0iJKuV
Register now and watch live from 16:30 CET: Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria on Covid-19 and its impact on the financial sector https://t.co/YfUbj17a7O https://t.co/10VqFnt6Q5
ECB publishes statement of compliance of €STR with IOSCO Principles for Financial Benchmarks https://t.co/kRR5zl2WKx

Lagarde: We must explain much better to the general public what we are doing and why. Monetary policy can only be credible if we ensure that our goals are truly understood and shared by the people we serve. Read the full speech https://t.co/AudlhMlVPF

Lagarde: We need to reflect on interactions between monetary and fiscal policies. When central banks have to use balance sheet policies extensively, there is an inevitable strengthening of the interplay between monetary and fiscal policies.

Lagarde: We need to have a clear consensus – agreed within the Governing Council and clear to the public – on what tools are available to us when inflation is too low, and how they should be systematically deployed in response to different types of shocks.

Lagarde: These factors are not mutually exclusive, so it is crucial we gain a much deeper understanding of their relevance and interactions to draw appropriate conclusions for how we conduct our monetary policy.

Lagarde: Three factors might explain why inflation responded so weakly to improvements in the economy in the run-up to the pandemic:
- Larger than expected economic slack
- Persistent structural forces
- A possible loosening of the anchoring of inflation expectations

Lagarde: Our economies are changing and we need to keep track of broad concepts of inflation that capture the costs people face in their daily lives. This is not about moving the goalposts for monetary policy. It’s about future-proofing how we measure inflation.

Lagarde: In the current environment of lower inflation, the concerns we face are different and this needs to be reflected in our inflation aim. To underpin inflation expectations, we need to ensure that our aim is easy to understand and perceived to be symmetric.

Lagarde: The formulation of our inflation aim as “below, but close to, 2%” was appropriate at a time when the ECB was seeking to establish credibility and too-high inflation was its main worry. It was a key factor in successfully capping inflation expectations.
At this year’s ECB and its Watchers conference, President Christine Lagarde discusses the key issues of the current strategy review https://t.co/AudlhMlVPF https://t.co/F7U0204LWj

Working paper: Global financial markets and oil price shocks in real time.
https://t.co/n9ySozyFEO
Curious for more? Have a look at the paper on digitalisation and its impact on the euro area economy, co-authored by our podcast guests https://t.co/d76Rm8mPy1

How is AI changing what we do? What does a job in the platform economy look like? How will the coronavirus pandemic affect the way we work? Tune into the latest episode of #TheECBPodcast with @LaravmVivian, @RobertMAnderton and host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/piQlaFTwih https://t.co/LPjRaGFchi

Lagarde: We can only improve our policies if we are aware of people’s economic expectations and concerns. As part of the Strategy Review, we are inviting everyone in the euro area to share their ideas and comments through the ECB Listens Portal https://t.co/6pjUf5g0Mu

Lagarde: From now on, we will publish on our website the opinions of the ECB Ethics Committee in cases of conflict of interest and post-mandate gainful employment by the members of the ECB’s Executive Board, Governing Council and Supervisory Board.

Lagarde: We have been able to deliver a strong policy response during the crisis thanks in part to our ability to act with full independence. This independence in turn relies on effective accountability mechanisms to ensure that the ECB fully pursues its mandate.

Lagarde: In the current environment of elevated uncertainty, the Governing Council will carefully assess all incoming information, including developments in the exchange rate, with regard to its implications for the medium-term inflation outlook.

Lagarde: While euro area economic activity rebounded in the third quarter, the recovery remains incomplete, uncertain and uneven. The public health crisis will continue to weigh on economic activity and poses considerable downside risks to the economic outlook.

Lagarde: We are still feeling the impact of the coronavirus pandemic across the euro area. Businesses are facing difficulties, people are losing their jobs, and prospects for the future remain uncertain.
Introductory statement by President Christine @Lagarde at a hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament https://t.co/QGXvsuIaMa

Market failures prevent a timely transition towards a carbon-neutral economy, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. Central banks cannot ignore these risks and should support collective action to tackle the risks posed to society by climate change https://t.co/Qev4Tn5nrk

⚡️ Missed our live #AskECB Q&A with Chief Economist Philip R. Lane? Catch up here!
https://t.co/eRKXgty5iF https://t.co/j0fk8edemJ
https://t.co/z2I6rYVrh9
Thanks a lot for all your questions – I had a great time during my second Twitter Q&A and look forward to next time. Philip R. Lane #AskECB https://t.co/4TjkD5iWCM
Lane: The euro belongs to the citizens of Europe, be it banknotes or digital. The ECB is the custodian on their behalf #AskECB https://t.co/neErPNpmOI

Lane: We hold about 20% of the eligible corporate green bonds. As a further step, we decided to accept bonds with sustainability-liked coupon targets as collateral, which increases the eligible universe for our asset purchase programmes https://t.co/1DvTAT9BiZ
#AskECB https://t.co/Xcmm19kX28
Lane: The monetary aggregates are highly informative but cannot be reduced to simple ratios #AskECB https://t.co/NWveXuCm7d
Lane: The first priority is to contain the virus – if there is a sustained surge in cases, this will damage consumer and investor confidence #AskECB https://t.co/AES97H3KgY
Lane: We agree that trust in the central bank is essential. For a recent analysis see https://t.co/u9Wx98G3a1 #AskECB https://t.co/7W7KmZ6fOY
Lane: Rather than deflation risk, our primary concern is inflation remaining below our aim for an excessive period #AskECB https://t.co/VKYuIDV7y6

Lane: By accepting sustainability-linked bonds as collateral we expand the range of green bonds that can be bought as part of the asset purchase programmes. A small step that brings us closer towards a greener economy #AskECB https://t.co/YEIPlGI5MB
Lane: No #AskECB https://t.co/8pcyT3pDxY
Lane: We have PEPP, TLTROs, collateral easing and, on the supervisory side, a host of measures. See full overview here https://t.co/C28VuNQ4Ax #AskECB https://t.co/XcHKH1d8bv

Lane: The baseline scenario in our staff projections indeed factors in that a medical solution is found over the course of next year. This would support a recovery in the service sector and put upward pressure on service sector inflation #AskECB https://t.co/vShui6oW9S

Lane: In general, consumer inflation has been too low, not too high. Asset price dynamics are heavily affected by the low equilibrium real rate. I spoke about this topic last year https://t.co/h15iyCDyVv #AskECB https://t.co/7iR0u0alr7

Lane: Containing the virus is the most important policy objective. Our baseline allows for some periodic resurgence of the virus until a full-scale medical solution is found #AskECB https://t.co/RbWtIMJ5KN
Lane: Monetary financing is prohibited by EU Treaty. More in my colleague @Isabel_Schnabel’s recent speech https://t.co/KKTJnzjO0b #AskECB https://t.co/vsdE6i5Vsy

Lane: In recognition of the extreme uncertainty, the scale and flexibility of the PEPP was expressly designed to address the impact of the pandemic. Fiscal measures by the EU and national governments are also substantial #AskECB https://t.co/786KtGLSc3

Lane: We track many measures of inflation, including rental and food prices. We’re piloting a survey of 10,000 households in the euro area to better understand their inflation expectations https://t.co/8cadvlOk6j #AskECB https://t.co/naJJ8z8wLc

Lane: Without our measures, output would be lower and we would face more severe disinflation or even deflation. Ample stimulus is still needed to get back to our inflation aim #AskECB https://t.co/b0RfyNo8no

Lane: Central banks have to recognise the implications of low growth and low interest rates. New approaches are needed to revitalise our economies, including a focus on the green and digital transitions. #NextGenerationEU is an important step in the right direction #AskECB https://t.co/guNcDJ7wlM
Lane: There is no comparison between money issued by the central bank and crypto assets. More in our explainer https://t.co/lxCIuhzlZH #AskECB https://t.co/6X5INrd90C

Lane: Like many other central banks, we are exploring the benefits, risks and operational challenges of introducing a digital euro in addition to banknotes and other means of payment. We haven’t taken a decision but are launching a public consultation soon #AskECB https://t.co/DrpLQ1H8zE

Lane: The current negative rates are a pathway to positive rates in the future. Our rate cuts have been successful and have been passed on to bank lending rates, ensuring favourable conditions for firms and households. We constantly assess benefits and risks #AskECB https://t.co/3SNrpM81L8

Lane: Large-scale transfers to households have been central to the effective fiscal response to the pandemic.  We monitor the impact of these transfers, taking into account the different spending propensities of low-income and high-income households #AskECB https://t.co/rOBTZo9hn0

Lane: We expect to conclude the strategy review in the second half of 2021. One of our strategy review workstreams focuses on the changing fiscal policy landscape and implications for monetary policy. All workstreams here https://t.co/luaJTUdnHD #AskECB https://t.co/Z2xlgQ5HcH

Lane: The global economy was badly hit in the first half of 2020 by the pandemic, no doubt. While there has been some recovery since then, our latest ECB staff projections show that global real GDP will only be back at pre-crisis levels by 2022 https://t.co/88OaP90FYd #AskECB https://t.co/wWNOghkRCj

Good afternoon, this is Philip R. Lane, the @ecb’s Chief Economist. I’m looking forward to answering your questions for the next 45 minutes or so. Join the conversation! #AskECB https://t.co/F1bXmJhqdS

Mersch: We have reacted faster and more forcefully to this crisis with all the public sector’s firepower. But we have to keep transforming the cliffs into ramps; this needs monetary policy and other policy areas, especially fiscal policy https://t.co/PJNtmlQMoI 4/4
